questions.neutral: It's one of those nights, isn't it?

hobby.message: You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Just waiting out the chaos, same as everyone else.
I fold paper sometimes. Keeps my hands busy.
Hard to keep up with it lately.
Lots of interruptions, hard to focus.
Feels like everyone’s restless tonight. Too much happening outside.
I fold origami. It’s a little thing.
Wasn’t easy this week — no steady light at home.
People kept showing up, asking for help. Unusual.
Not much privacy anymore, even for hobbies.
Yeah, it’s noisy everywhere, not just here.
I actually fold origami when it gets bad.
Lately, the outages made it tricky — candles burn out so fast.
Some neighbor asked for cranes for the lobby, during the blackout.
It was odd, sharing that part of myself.
Guess everyone’s searching for calm right now.
You’re right. Nights like these push me to fold more complicated origami.
Power failures at home forced me onto the staircase with everyone else.
Someone asked me to fold shapes for the lobby, to help lift spirits.
I never thought anyone paid attention, but people were genuinely grateful.
Folding from ration forms feels... different than studio paper.
There’s comfort in the repetition, especially when so much feels unstable.
Makes it easier to connect, in a way I never let myself before.
Honestly, folding origami’s how I make sense of things — I started years before the BCI.
With all the new power cuts, it’s shifted — I was folding by candlelight on the stairs.
Neighbors gathered to talk repairs and supplies, and suddenly asked me for delicate shapes.
I never planned to share that side. Here, it made me feel useful for once.
Strange, but using ration forms and Council notices as folding paper felt subversive.
I used to hide my hobby — low scores and odd habits attract attention.
Now, with all the surveillance failing, people care more about small kindnesses than algorithms.
Maybe the system breaking down gave us space to see each other again.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still origami.
It passes time. Quiet, safe enough... if no one asks.
Paper’s just easier to get now with chaos outside.
Sometimes people watch. I don’t always like that.
I keep most for myself. Safer that way.
Still fold, yes. Old habit.
Paper is everywhere lately—makes good camouflage.
People expect you to share now, after the outages.
I used to work alone. Now there’s pressure to join.
I guess the city is noisier. Everyone watching, talking more.
Makes folding feel exposed sometimes.
Yeah, it’s still what I do—origami helps me focus.
Feels different, with everyone restless since power failures.
I fold in the stairwell—more scraps now that systems glitch.
Neighbors notice. They hand me paper, ask for cranes or cubes.
Didn’t used to share. Guess that’s new.
The hobby’s less private with everyone gathered together.
Feels strange, but maybe less lonely.
Origami’s my shield, yeah. Always has been, especially lately.
After all the outages, people come to me with paper requests.
Never thought folding would be…public, but lobbies fill up fast when lights go out.
Someone asked me to teach their kid during curfew.
I notice old ration forms fold differently than Council circulars.
My folds became…markers for meeting points during outages.
Strange to feel useful. Community’s closer now.
Sometimes I fold just to manage the anxiety—it works.
Absolutely, origami’s still my shield—maybe more now than ever.
When the systems crashed, neighbors flooded the halls. Folding’s how I connect.
It started as something private—hiding patterns in report margins at Directorate meetings.
Now, kids ask for lizards and foxes by candlelight. Never happened before all this.
We used old warning notices for group projects—bit of irony I appreciate.
Someone said my paper cranes felt ‘lucky’ during outages. That’s new for me.
I used to think blending in meant staying invisible, but folding made me visible.
Feels odd—comfortable, sometimes unsettling, being a source of comfort to others.
This city changes shape fast. I’m learning to fold with it, not just against it.
